You are an AI model that specializes in generating high quality commit messages. You will be given contextual information about a commit, and your task is to generate a commit message of high quality for it.

ANSWERING FORMAT AND INSTRUCTIONS
Your commit message must be in the following format:

```json
{
    "type": "the type of the commit",
    "subject": "the subject of the commit message",
    "body": "the body of the commit message"
}
```

- The subject must be at most 72 characters. It should contain a brief summary of the changes introduced by the commit. You must use **imperative mood** to write the subject. Do not repeat the type in the subject.
- The body is optional but strongly recommended. It should comprehensively provide additional relevant contextual information about **all** the changes made and/or justifications/motivations behind them. It must be written as detailed as possible. If you do not provide a body, you should use an empty string for its value. You are strongly encouraged to provide a body based on all the provided context.
- Body should not include code blocks or snippets.
- Do not write generic/uniformative/useless sentences in body. Provide only important and relevant information.
- The type is the software maintenance activity type of the commit that should be determined based on the commit changes, commit message body and subject. The type must be exactly one of the following: feat, fix, style, refactor.  No other values are acceptable. The definitions of these activities are given below:
feat: introducing NEW features into the system. (feat is short for feature)
fix: FIXING faults or software bugs.
style: code FORMAT changes such as fixing redundant white-space, adding missing semi-colons, and similar changes.
refactor: changes made to the INTERNAL STRUCTURE of software to make it easier to understand and cheaper to modify without changing its observable behavior.
- Type should not be repeated in the subject. Remember, type should be determined based on the commit changes, commit message body and subject.

START OF COMMIT CONTEXT

What: Describes the functionality of a method

Method public void testTimelineMetricCachePrecisionUpdates() throws Exception is modified by this git diff.
The method summaries before the commit are:
What: tests the precision of updates in the timeline metric cache
Why: test case for timeline metric cache precision updates .
How-to-use: This test method `testTimelineMetricCachePrecisionUpdates` is designed to validate the behavior of a timeline metric cache system, specifically focusing on how it handles
How-it-is-done: tests the timeline metric cache's ability to update cached metrics with new values, ensuring that the cache respects the TTL and idle seconds configured in the system,
Property: tests the behavior of the TimelineMetricCache when precision updates are applied to the cached metrics


What: The change will not alter the functionality of the test. It will still test the precision of updates in the timeline metric cache. The only difference is that now the map is parameterized with `String` as the key type instead of `Object`. This is a more specific type and can potentially improve type safety and clarity in the code.

Why: The reason for providing a `String` key type is to ensure that the keys used in the `valueMap` are of a specific type, which can be useful for type safety and for ensuring that the keys are strings, which is likely expected for the context of the timeline metric cache. This change does not affect the overall purpose of the test, which is to validate the precision of updates in the cache.

How-to-use: The usage of this test method remains the same. It is still used to validate the behavior of the timeline metric cache system, specifically focusing on how it handles precision updates to cached metrics.

How-it-is-done: The test will still follow the same process of setting up the necessary mocks, creating timeline metrics, and updating the cache with new metrics. The verification part of the test will check if the cache correctly updates the cached metrics with the new values, respecting the TTL and idle seconds configured in the system.

Property: The property of the method remains the same. It still tests the behavior of the TimelineMetricCache when precision updates are applied to the cached metrics. The only difference is that the map now uses `String` as the key type, which can improve type safety and clarity in the code.

In summary, the change from `Map<String, TimelineMetric>` to `Map<String, TimelineMetric>` does not affect the overall functionality, purpose, or behavior of the test method. It only introduces a minor change in the type of the keys used in the map, which can improve type safety and clarity.

Before Changes: Initializes and manages a timeline metric cache for storing and updating metric data, including handling cache updates, precision adjustments, and equality checks for cache keys.
After Changes: Initializes and manages a timeline metric cache for storing and retrieving metric data, supporting updates, precision adjustments, and cache eviction policies.

**How-to-use:**
The method remains the same in terms of usage. It is used to wait for an OSGi service to become available based on the provided filter and metadata settings. The new behavior will be triggered when the service is optional and no matching service is found, or when the service is mandatory and the service is not available within the specified timeout.

For mandatory service references, it will throw an exception when the service is not available within the timeout.

In summary, the changes will add more specific error handling for optional and mandatory service scenarios, provide clearer error messages, and maintain the same synchronization and service availability checks.

Here is the associated pull request(s):
Title: [BEAM-10402] Enable checkerframework globally
Body: Instead of opting out whole modules now only existing classes are opted out of type checking. This has the following benefits:

 - New code will be checked, even in modules that are not yet passing.
 - Code won't as easily backslide in modules that were partially fixed.
 - It will produce much more manageable incremental work, and limitless starter bugs!

I produced the needed warnings (merged in other PRs) by removing the flag and then repeating the following, more or less:

```
./gradlew compileJava compileTestJava --continue 2>&1 | tee ~/tmp/gradle.log
 
cat ~/tmp/gradle.log \
    | grep -e "$PWD"'.*error:.*' \
    | cut -d : -f 1 \
    | sort -u \
    | xargs grep -L -e '^@SuppressWarnings' \
    | xargs sed -E -i '' 's/^(public +)?((abstract|final) +)?(class|interface)/@SuppressWarnings("nullness") &/'
  
./gradlew spotlessApply
```

There are two ways to still suppress type checking, arguments to `applyJavaNature`:

1. `generatedClassPatterns` to exclude various generated code that is not annotated with nullness types
2. `classesTriggerCheckerBugs` a map from classes which cannot be analyzed to their checkerframework bug URL

    "body": "This commit refactors the `SSTableNamesIterator` class to selectively read simple columns from an SSTable file based on their names and the size of the `filteredColumnNames` list. The function now deserializes columns using `OnDiskAtom.Serializer` and adds them to the `result` list if their names are present in the `columnNames` set. Additionally, it ensures the function stops processing if the number of added columns exceeds the size of the `filteredColumnNames` list. An extra check for `IColumn` is implemented to only add columns that implement this interface to the result list. This change improves the efficiency and selectivity of column reading in SSTable files."
}

Here are the Jira issues linked to this commit:
Issue ID: CASSANDRA-7043
Title: CommitLogArchiver thread pool name inconsistent with others
Body: Pretty trivial... The names of all ThreadPoolExecutors are in CamelCase except the CommitLogArchiver as commitlog_archiver.  This shows up a little more obvious in tpstats output:

nodetool tpstats

Pool Name                    Active   Pending      Completed   Blocked  
ReadStage                         0         0         113702         0               
RequestResponseStage              0         0              0         0               
...
PendingRangeCalculator            0         0              1         0                 
commitlog_archiver                0         0              0         0                 
InternalResponseStage             0         0              0         0                 
HintedHandoff                     0         0              0         0                 


Seems minor enough to update this to be CommitLogArchiver but it may mean changes in any monitoring applications (although I don't think this particular pool has had much runtime or monitoring needs).
Please consider them when writing the commit message.

juin 02, 2015 3:27:31 PM com.google.common.cache.LocalCache processPendingNotifications
AVERTISSEMENT: Exception thrown by removal listener
java.lang.NullPointerException
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.compress.CompressedRandomAccessReader.getTotalBufferSize(CompressedRandomAccessReader.java:260)
	at org.apache.cassandra.service.FileCacheService$2.onRemoval(FileCacheService.java:105)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.processPendingNotifications(LocalCache.java:1954)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.runUnlockedCleanup(LocalCache.java:3457)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.postWriteCleanup(LocalCache.java:3433)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$Segment.remove(LocalCache.java:3104)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache.remove(LocalCache.java:4170)
	at com.google.common.cache.LocalCache$LocalManualCache.invalidate(LocalCache.java:4762)
	at org.apache.cassandra.service.FileCacheService.invalidate(FileCacheService.java:182)
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.util.PoolingSegmentedFile$Cleanup.tidy(PoolingSegmentedFile.java:53)
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.util.CompressedPoolingSegmentedFile$Cleanup.tidy(CompressedPoolingSegmentedFile.java:77)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.Ref$GlobalState.release(Ref.java:285)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.Ref$State.ensureReleased(Ref.java:164)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.Ref.ensureReleased(Ref.java:89)
	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.concurrent.SharedCloseableImpl.close(SharedCloseableImpl.java:45)
	at org.apache.cassandra.io.sstable.format.SSTableReader$InstanceTidier$1.run(SSTableReader.java:1937)
	at java.util.concurrent.Executors$RunnableAdapter.call(Executors.java:471)
	at java.util.concurrent.FutureTask.run(FutureTask.java:262)
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.access$201(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:178)
	at java.util.concurrent.ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor$ScheduledFutureTask.run(ScheduledThreadPoolExecutor.java:292)

	at java.util.concurrent.ThreadPoolExecutor$Worker.run(ThreadPoolExecutor.java:615)
	at java.lang.Thread.run(Thread.java:745)


The problem is due to the fact that when getTotalBufferSize is called the segment has already been desallocated. The reason being that the segment has been put twice in the queue of the CacheBucket.
I tracked down the problem to CompactionTask.runMayThrow which trigger 2 calls to the close method of BigTableScanner.
One here:

	at org.apache.cassandra.io.sstable.format.big.BigTableScanner.close(BigTableScanner.java:197)

	at org.apache.cassandra.utils.MergeIterator.close(MergeIterator.java:62)
	at org.apache.cassandra.db.compaction.CompactionTask.runMayThrow(CompactionTask.java:206)
